awd_titl_txt: EFRI C3 SoRo: Muscle-like Cellular Architectures and Compliant, Distributed Sensing and Control for Soft Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create a systematic and scalable approach to the design and construction of soft robots. Soft robots have many potential advantages over traditional rigid robots, such as being able to interact safely with people and their surroundings. This project will accelerate the deployment of practical soft robots by exploring modular configurations inspired by natural muscles. Muscular structures can achieve extraordinary feats of dexterity and manipulation even in the absence of a rigid skeleton, with elephant trunks, cephalopod tentacles, and mammalian tongues as prominent examples. Biological muscles operate with hundreds to thousands of individual actuating units and multiple channels for sensing. This research will take inspiration from the structure of biological muscle to construct dexterous, flexible and highly controllable actuators, with distributed sensing, computation, and communication integrated throughout.
 
This project draws inspiration from biology for the investigation and development of a new class of soft robots that are modular and hierarchically arranged. Soft, muscle-cell-like units will be developed that can be inexpensively fabricated at a range of sizes, and implemented en masse to produce customized compliant and continuum robotic structures. Methods will be explored to utilize simple linear actuators to produce complex spatial deformation. Implementation of passive stiffening elements, such as fibers, throughout the soft structures will be evaluated for improving output motion and stiffness relative to what can be produced by the soft structure and actuators alone. The research team will also investigate sensing, power, and control of these systems through the development of electric and magnetic field-based sensors that obviate the need for extensive wiring. Finally, the research team will investigate the modeling and control of the soft, muscle-like structures in order to enable effective planning and execution of mechanically complex manipulation and locomotion tasks. The proposed new approaches for wireless power, sensing, and control of soft robots have the potential to be broadly applicable to many soft robotic architectures and to change the approaches commonly utilized in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Work on this project centered around exploring a concept related to the feasibility of small, simple electro-mechanical modules that might be used do develop larger complete robot systems. The modularity is similar to how biological muscle is organized, and so we focused on four major sub-topics: muscle mechanics; design of muscle-like soft robot structures; sensing, power, and communication for highly deformable robots; and planning and control for these systems.      

One aspect of the problem that we focused on was the question of how different arrangements of actuator modules provided different mechanical and actuation behavior of the fabricated structures. Accordingly, we conducted a thorough examination of the range of possible lattice structures that could be produced with identical actuator modules, and examined them according to the stiffness and strain (shape-changing) behaviors that result. These behaviors are a function of both the lattice structure mechanics as well as the mechanics of the individual robot “cells”. We published these studies in a series of journal papers, and the results apply not only to modular robotic structures, but can help inform muscle mechanics as well.

A central aim of the project was to use inspiration from biological actuators to inform design of multi-element, three-dimensional soft robot actuators. The project advanced our understanding of the structural elements underlying the three-dimensional deformation that occurs when skeletal muscles produce force. A series of experiments combining data from physical models and isolated muscles demonstrated how muscle force output is influenced by the physical interaction of fluid, collagen fibers, and muscle contractile proteins. These studies advanced our understanding of how the three-dimensional deformation of skeletal muscle during contraction is determined by the interplay of active contractile elements and passive structures, providing further inspiration for soft robotic actuators that combine active and passive elements.

Another goal of the project was to develop methods to control a soft robot to manipulate every-day objects as deftly as humans.  For this to be possible, a robot would need to have a sense of touch and be able to use that sense to control its limbs and fingers as they contact an object. To develop such a controller, simulation tools and low-cost tactile sensors were implemented as part of this project.  Further, real-world experiments were conducted and corresponding simulations were run to develop a neural network capable of controlling the robot in ways that utilized its sense of touch.  A final series of experiments were performed to evaluate the robot's ability to master skills fundamental to dexterous manipulation.  The results showed that robots equipped only with low-cost, information-poor tactile sensors are able to perform basic manipulation tasks.  These results provide motivation to further study how humans learn to use tactile and kinesthetic feedback to control their limbs during execution of dexterous tasks, and how they adapt their controller when such feedback is reduced as a result of illness or injury.

We also developed a new approach to creating lightweight arm mechanisms with many degrees of freedom. The key idea is to replace fully actuated joints (with one motor per joint) with electrostatic brakes. Electrostatic brakes consist of thin conductive plates separated by a dielectric. When a voltage is applied across the plates, electrostatic attraction causes them to stick together, increasing friction and stopping a joint. An electrostatic brake is much lighter than a comparable motor. Our paper compared the mechanical performance of electrostatic brakes to that of biological muscle and conventional motors. Properly designed electrostatic brakes can exhibit specific holding torques that are comparable to biological muscle. Using electrostatic brakes, we built a 10 degree-of-freedom arm actuated with a single motor that can be placed in any pose by applying the right sequence of motor and braking commands. (Note that it cannot generate an arbitrary trajectory, the way a fully actuated arm could; the decrease in weight and complexity is paid for by the need to time multiplex the single motor across all of the joints.) In a parallel effort, we collaborated with a team studying the octopus, collecting data on real octopus arm search behavior to that generated by a computational model of octopus arm control.
